summary: This document is an email chain from May 2020 between U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) prosecutors and FBI personnel regarding the processing and transfer of electronic evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's New York and US Virgin Islands residences. The emails discuss difficulties in organizing, identifying, and transferring terabytes of data from numerous devices, including computers, hard drives, and loose media, for review in the Epstein case.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The case involves evidence seized from his residences in New York and the US Virgin Islands. He is the central figure in the investigation.

events.title: Previous property search
events.description: Mention of a July 2007 search on one of Epstein's properties, where 9 IDE hard drives (3 copies of 3 drives) were found in his Manhattan apartment.

events.title: Evidence transfer coordination
events.description: Ongoing emails in May 2020 between the U.S. Attorney's Office and FBI regarding the transfer and processing of electronic evidence seized from Epstein's properties, highlighting organizational challenges and the volume of data.

locations: Southern District of New York (SDNY) U.S. Attorney's Office
keyFacts: Extensive electronic evidence was seized from Jeffrey Epstein's New York and US Virgin Islands residences, including computers, servers, hard drives, thumb drives, CDs, phones, tablets, cameras, and DVRs, totaling terabytes of data.

The U.S. Attorney's Office was experiencing significant difficulties in processing and reviewing the evidence due to formatting issues, lack of device attribution, and problems linking emails to attachments.
Evidence included 9 IDE hard drives from a July 2007 search on an Epstein property, found to be 3 copies of 3 drives.
The FBI and prosecutors were coordinating in May 2020 to transfer raw data from seized devices, with a focus on properly identifying each device by serial number and seizure location.
The document reveals the massive scale and complexity of the digital evidence collection in the Epstein case, posing challenges for legal review and discovery.
